intro: Androsace alpina var. mathildae, commonly known as the Alpine Androsace, is a low-growing perennial plant native to alpine regions of Europe. It belongs to the family Primulaceae and is characterized by its rosette of small, fleshy, spoon-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of white or pinkish flowers in the spring, which are borne on short, hairy stems. It thrives in well-drained, rocky soils and is adapted to cold, high-altitude environments. This variety is often found in mountain meadows and is valued for its ornamental appeal in rock gardens.
